analyzed: upāntyataḥ antya samīpāt nivarteta vyādyudyeta

analyzed: tyajan pariharan ekaikam ūrdhva bhāgāt

original: evamanena prakāreṇa kasmādiyaṃ ekadvyādilagukriyāṃ pravartata ityāha /

translated: Thus, by this method, why is this operation of one, two, etc. performed? He says:

analyzed: upari ādyāt guroḥ iti upari sthitān ādyāt guroḥ

analyzed: kaḥ rthaḥ

analyzed: sarva guru varṇa vṛtta sakāśāt iti arthaḥ

analyzed: ādyam kila sarva guru akṣaram ekam vṛttam parikalpate

analyzed: etat ca prastāre darśitam yathā

translated: By placing a light syllable below all heavy syllables from the beginning, therefore, this operation of light syllables beginning with one and two proceeds from that.

original: tatra paṃcasu varṇeṣu uttarādharabhāvena sthāpiteṣu adhaḥsthita ekastaduparisthe nikṣipyate /
analyzed: tatra paṃcasu varṇeṣu uttara adhara bhāvena sthāpiteṣu adhas sthitaḥ ekaḥ tad upari sthe nikṣipyate
translated: There, when five syllables are placed in a higher and lower position, the one located below is placed on the one located above.

original: sa ca tathaiva tiṣṭhati tyajannekaikamūrdhvata iti vīpsavaśādekadaiva sthitimaṃtareṇa
analyzed: sa ca tathā eva tiṣṭhati tyajan ekaikam ūrdhvatas iti vīpsa vaśāt ekadā eva sthitim aṃtareṇa
translated: And that remains just as it is, abandoning each one above, by the force of the iterative, simultaneously without remaining.

original: nikṣiptatvāt punarnikṣepabhāvādekaikatyāgaśca na saṃbhavati tasmātsvarūpeṇa sthita
analyzed: nikṣipta tvāt punar nikṣepa bhāvāt ekaika tyāgaḥ ca na saṃbhavati tasmāt sva rūpeṇa sthita
translated: Because it is placed, it is not possible to abandon each one again due to the state of being placed. Therefore, it remains in its own form.

analyzed: eva upari kṣipyate

original: tato dvitīye sthāne dvau varṇau bhavataḥ tau tṛtīyena kṣipyeta tatra trayo bhavanti /

translated: Then in the second place there are two syllables. They are placed in the third. There are three.

original: tacca caturthe nikṣipyante te catvāro bhavanti /
analyzed: tat ca caturthe nikṣipyante te catvāraḥ bhavanti
translated: And that is placed in the fourth. They become four.

analyzed: upāntyataḥ nivartate tyajan ekaikam ūrdhvatas uparitanam ekam tyajyate tatra na kṣipyate iti arthaḥ
translated: Abandoning each one above, it turns back from the penultimate. The one above is abandoned. The meaning is that it is not placed there.

original: vīpsā ta eva adhobhāgāt punarnikṣepe kriyā pravartate tena adhaḥsthita eva eko dvitīye sthāne nikṣipyate tatra ca trayo bhavanti /
analyzed: vīpsā te eva adhobhāgāt punarnikṣepe kriyā pravartate tena adhas sthitaḥ eva ekaḥ dvitīye sthāne nikṣipyate tatra ca trayaḥ bhavanti
translated: The repetition is that very [process] again below. The action proceeds by placing [the syllables] below. Therefore, only one located below is placed in the second position, and there are three of them.

original: tacca tṛtīye nikṣipyante tatra ṣaṭbhavanti upari ekaṃ tyajannivarteta /
analyzed: tat ca tṛtīye nikṣipyante tatra ṣaṭ bhavanti upari ekam tyajan nivarteta
translated: And that is placed in the third, and there are six. Abandoning one above, one would return.

original: ādyaṃ ekaṃ vṛttaṃ sarvaguruḥ tasmāddekadvyādilagukriyā pravartete /
analyzed: ādyam ekam vṛttam sarva guruḥ pravartete
translated: The first circle is all heavy. From that, the operation of one, two, etc. light syllables proceeds.

original: tata ekaḥ sarvaguruḥ catvāri dvilaghūni ṣaṭtrilaghūni catvāri caturlaghūni ekaṃ sarvalaghuḥ
analyzed: tatas ekaḥ sarva guruḥ catvāri dvi laghūni ṣaṣ tri laghūni catvāri catur laghūni ekam sarva laghuḥ
translated: Then one is all heavy, four are two light, six are three light, four are four light, and one is all light.

original: eṣā lagukriyā sarvalaghuprastāreṇa pratīyate asyāstu eṣa eva kramaḥ paṃcākṣarādivṛtteṣvapi // //

translated: This operation of light syllables is understood by the arrangement of all light [syllables]. But this very sequence is also in the circles of five syllables and so on.

translated: In the class of four-syllable meters, the sum of the numbers that are twice the number of circles that are recited is fifteen, with one added it is sixteen.🔽The Yoga of the Path
